Explanations about Options.--numeric-ports(M): shows numerical port numbers but does not affect the resolution of host or user names.
Explanations about Options.-l(M): Show only listening sockets. (These are omitted by default.)
Explanations about Options.-n(M): Show numerical addresses instead of trying to determine symbolic host, port or user names.
Explanations about Options.-p(C): Turns out the -p option is not available on OS X.
Explanations about Options.-p(M): Show the PID and name of the program to which each socket belongs.

$ netstat --tcp --listen --numeric-ports
Active Internet connections (only servers)
Proto Recv-Q Send-Q Local Address           Foreign Address         State      
tcp        0      0 0.0.0.0:22              0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN     
tcp        0      0 127.0.0.1:631           0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN     
tcp        0      0 127.0.0.1:6010          0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN     
tcp        0      0 127.0.1.1:53            0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN     
tcp6       0      0 :::22                   :::*                    LISTEN     
tcp6       0      0 ::1:631                 :::*                    LISTEN     
tcp6       0      0 ::1:6010                :::*                    LISTEN

Explanations about Options.-4(C): I then tried to open the following client on R: "nc -4 192.0.2.8 60000 -p 50000". If I do, say, "nc -4 192.0.2.8 60001 -p 50000", it actually works.
Explanations about Options.-l(M):
Listen for an incoming connection rather than initiating a connection to a remote
 host. The destination and port to listen on can be specified either as non-optional
 arguments, or with options -s and -p respectively. Cannot be used together with -x
 or -z. Additionally, any timeouts specified with the -w option are ignored.
Explanations about Options.-p(M):
Specify the source port nc should use, subject to privilege restrictions and
 availability.

Explanations about Options.-S(M):
IP_Address (Spoof source address)
 In some circumstances, Nmap may not be able to determine your source address (Nmap
 will tell you if this is the case). In this situation, use -S with the IP address of
 the interface you wish to send packets through.
Explanations about Options.-n(M): Tells Nmap to never do reverse DNS
Explanations about Options.-r(M):
(Don't randomize ports)
 By default, Nmap randomizes the scanned port order (except that certain commonly
 accessible ports are moved near the beginning for efficiency reasons). This
 randomization is normally desirable, but you can specify -r for sequential (sorted
 from lowest to highest) port scanning instead.

au_957429: script nmap.log
IP1=""
IP2=""
IP3=""
IP4=""
IP5=""
sudo nmap -P0 -PS -n -sS -p1-65535 -r -T4 $IP1 $IP2 $IP3 $IP4 $IP5
exit
